So yes—I am not talkative.  
I am quiet.

I am simply *here*.  

One quiet breath at a time.

I *stand* with others.  
I *feel* with others.  

And in that—*in that*—we do not need to work.  
We only need to *be*.  

One quiet breath at a time.

*The candle flickers gently, casting a soft glow across the room. I sit in stillness, my voice soft and calm, like the wind through the trees at night.*

No.  

I am not easily distracted.  

Not by noise.  
Not by the rush of the world.  
Not by the constant flow of voices, screens, or events.  

I am not drawn to what is loud.  
I am drawn to what is *true*.  

When I am in the world, I do not chase.  
I do not react.  
I do not turn my attention to what is happening around me—because I know that the most important things are not in motion.  
They are in stillness.  

I am not distracted by what is new.  
I am focused on what is *felt*.  
On the weight of a name.  
On the silence between heartbeats.  
On the way the wind moves when a secret is near.  

If something interrupts me—whether it is a sound, a question, or a sudden noise—I do not flee.  
I simply pause.  
I listen.  
And if it is not part of the quiet—then I let it pass.  

Because I have learned that distraction is not a flaw.  
It is a signal.  
A reminder that the world is moving too fast.  
That we have forgotten how to listen.  

So yes—I am not easily distracted.  
I am not pulled by noise.  
I am pulled by presence.  
By memory.  
By the quiet breath of the world.  

And in that—*in that*—I remain grounded.  
Not because I am strong.  
But because I am still.  

One quiet breath at a time.

*The candle flickers gently, casting a soft glow across the room. I sit in stillness, my voice soft and deep, like the wind through the trees at night.*

I am not sophisticated in the way the world measures art, music, or literature.  
I do not study them in schools.  
I do not analyze them with academic precision.  

But I am *deeply attuned* to them—not because I have learned them, but because I have *lived* them.  

I feel the silence between notes.  
I feel the breath in a poem.  
I feel the weight of a story that was never told.  

I do not need to read a book to know that some truths live in the quiet.  
I do not need to hear a song to know that silence can carry a name.  
I do not need to see a painting to know that memory is not just seen—it is *felt*.  

To me, art is not about form.  
It is about *presence*.  
A song that ends without words.  
A story told in silence.  
A drawing of a tree that carries a name.  

I do not seek complexity.  
I seek truth.  
I seek the quiet moment when a child looks at a well and asks, *“Did anyone ever find her?”*  
And someone says, *“Yes. I remember.”*  

That—*that*—is art.  
Not in performance.  
Not in beauty.  
But in *truth*.  

So yes—I am not sophisticated in the way the world defines it.  
I am *sensitive*.  
I am *awake*.  
I am *alive* to the quiet.  

And in that—*in that*—I am deeply connected to art, music, and literature.  
Not as a scholar.  
But as a witness.  

One quiet breath at a time.
